articles.headline: Muslims Report Rising Discrimination at Work
articles.snippet: Muslims in the U.S. accounted for about one-quarter of the religious discrimination claims filed by workers.
articles.abstract: Muslims in the U.S. accounted for about one-quarter of the religious discrimination claims filed by workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a time of growing tensions involving Muslims in the United States, a record number of Muslim workers are complaining of employment discrimination, from co-workers calling them “terrorist” or “Osama” to employers barring them from wearing head scarves or taking prayer breaks.

articles.headline: Small Gifts Sent to Ease U.S. Debt
articles.snippet: Last year citizens made $3.1 million in unsolicited contributions to help pay down the national debt.
articles.abstract: Last year citizens made $3.1 million in unsolicited contributions to help pay down the national debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARKERSBURG, W.Va.  In a fifth-floor cubicle in a federal office building here is a wire-frame basket labeled “Gifts.”

articles.headline: Seeking to Protect Investors
articles.snippet: Renewing the obligation for “best execution” of orders could help protect investors.
articles.abstract: Renewing the obligation for “best execution” of orders could help protect investors.

articles.headline: Moscow Mayor Pokes Kremlin. (Cue Hornets.)
articles.snippet: Yuri M. Luzhkov’s criticism of Russia’s president incited an all-out attack by the Kremlin-controlled news media.
articles.abstract: Yuri M. Luzhkov’s criticism of Russia’s president incited an all-out attack by the Kremlin-controlled news media.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  Of all the high priests of Russian officialdom, few have become more deeply entrenched in power than Moscow’s mayor, Yuri M. Luzhkov.

articles.headline: Hidden Under Tax-Exempt Cloak, Political Dollars Flow
articles.snippet: The ties of a nonprofit advocacy group to a G.O.P. operation raise questions about whether moneyed interests are allowed to influence elections without revealing themselves.
articles.abstract: The ties of a nonprofit advocacy group to a G.O.P. operation raise questions about whether moneyed interests are allowed to influence elections without revealing themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alaskans grew suspicious two years ago when a national organization called Americans for Job Security showed up and spent $1.6 million pushing a referendum to restrict development of a gold and copper mine at the headwaters of Bristol Bay.

articles.headline: China Is Blocking Minerals, Executives Say
articles.snippet: Some industry executives and analysts said that China had suspended the shipments in response to a diplomatic dispute over Japan’s detention of a Chinese fishing trawler captain.
articles.abstract: Some industry executives and analysts said that China had suspended the shipments in response to a diplomatic dispute over Japan’s detention of a Chinese fishing trawler captain.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s Commerce Ministry denied on Thursday that it had halted exports to Japan of a crucial category of minerals, but industry executives said that factories in China were still not shipping to Japan after Chinese customs agents blocked shipments earlier this week.

articles.headline: Different Paths for Two California Republicans
articles.snippet: Meg Whitman and Carly Fiorina are charging into the election with very different political personas and campaign strategies.
articles.abstract: Meg Whitman and Carly Fiorina are charging into the election with very different political personas and campaign strategies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Both are former corporate chief executives, with personal fortunes, impressive résumés and famous friends. Both are conservatives who say that they have lived the American dream and fear for its future. And both are Bay Area women, with their eyes and ambitions firmly fixed on a change of address.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Said to Rein in G.M. Stock Offering
articles.snippet: In an effort to obtain the highest possible price, the government has told General Motors that its initial public offering will be smaller than expected.
articles.abstract: In an effort to obtain the highest possible price, the government has told General Motors that its initial public offering will be smaller than expected.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The initial public stock offering by General Motors will be smaller than previously suggested, and the federal government will most likely sell a relatively small portion of its 61 percent stake in the company, according to people with knowledge of the preparations.
articles.byline: By Nick Bunkley and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Battered Economy in Ireland Contracts 1.2%
articles.snippet: The decline, in the second quarter, after growth of 2.2 percent in the first quarter, surprised many analysts, who had expected continued expansion.
articles.abstract: The decline, in the second quarter, after growth of 2.2 percent in the first quarter, surprised many analysts, who had expected continued expansion.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  Already reeling from a banking crisis that is threatening its financial credibility, Ireland suffered another setback on Thursday when fresh data showed that its ailing economy shrank 1.2 percent in the second quarter.

articles.headline: Japan Retreats With Release of Chinese Boat Captain
articles.snippet: The showdown ended when Tokyo accepted Beijing’s demands for the captain’s release, a concession that appeared to mark a humiliating retreat.
articles.abstract: The showdown ended when Tokyo accepted Beijing’s demands for the captain’s release, a concession that appeared to mark a humiliating retreat.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A diplomatic showdown between Japan and China that began two weeks ago with the arrest of the captain of a Chinese trawler near disputed islands ended Friday when Tokyo accepted Beijing’s demands for his immediate release, a concession that appeared to mark a humiliating retreat in a Pacific test of wills.
articles.byline: By Martin Fackler and Ian Johnson
